record_data.record_title: Review of Funding Adequacy & Future DOE Recovery Application
record_data.record_plain_text: Appendix E Review of Adequacy of Funding and Application of Future DOE Recoveries 1. Connecticut Yankee ("Yankee") has brought a civil action against the U.S. Department of Energy ("DOE") to recover damages suffered by Yankee during the period 2002 through 2008 caused by the failure of DOE to perform its obligations under its Standard Contract with Yankee under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982, and Yankee plans to file additional civil actions against the DOE to recover additional damages with respect to subsequent periods until DOE fully performs its obligations. Yankee shall apply any damages recovered from DOE in any such civil action and any proceeds received from DOE in settlement of any such civil action ("DOE Proceeds") as follows: a. Any DOE Proceeds that Yankee receives shall be applied as follows: i. First, the DOE Proceeds shall be applied to pay federal and state taxes due on the DOE Proceeds received; ii. Second, the remaining DOE Proceeds, if any, shall be deposited in the Decommissioning Trust Funds to the extent necessary to maintain the Financial Assurance Level, as defined in section 1(b) of this Appendix E; iii. Third, the remaining DOE Proceeds, if any, shall be deposited in an external trust fund to the extent necessary to fund Yankee's expense for post-retirement benefits other than pensions, after taxes, at the level most recently approved by the Commission. iv. Fourth, the remaining DOE Proceeds, if any, shall be applied to reduce uniformly any scheduled charges for funding of the Decommissioning Trust Funds; and v. Fifth, the remaining DOE Proceeds, if any, shall be credited to Purchasers in the manner set forth in section 2 of this Appendix E, below. b. For purposes of this Appendix E, "Financial Assurance Level" shall mean the funding required to be held in the Decommissioning Trust Funds to meet projected decommissioning costs, including costs of operating and maintaining the ISFSI and the costs of dismantling and decontaminating the ISFSI and the payment to DOE of the Spent Fuel Obligation associated with pre-1983 spent nuclear fuel. In calculating the Financial Assurance Level, Yankee shall use: i. the cost estimate and all associated financial assumptions most recently accepted by the FERC prior to the calculation of the Financial Assurance Level, except as specified in section 1(c), below; ii. information from the end of the most recent calendar quarter for which data are available with respect to (i) actual trust fund balances, (ii) actual trust fund investment earnings; (iii) actual decommissioning costs; and (iv) actual escalation of the Spent Fuel Obligation associated with pre-1983 spent nuclear fuel; and iii. the assumption that Yankee shall remain in operation for purposes of operating the ISFSI, decontaminating and dismantling the ISFSI and winding up its corporate affairs for a period of fifteen years after the date with respect to which the Financial Assurance Level is calculated, notwithstanding the date projected for the end of Yankee's corporate life in the cost estimate, unless section 1(d), below, applies; c. If Yankee has submitted a revised decommissioning cost estimate to the FERC that is pending before the FERC at the time Yankee is calculating the Financial Assurance Level, Yankee shall initially use the pending cost estimate and associated financial assumptions to calculate the Financial Assurance Level, provided that the calculation shall be trued-up to reflect any revisions to the cost estimate and financial assumptions required by the resolution of proceedings on the pending estimate. d. Once DOE has begun to transfer spent nuclear fuel from Yankee's ISFSI to a repository operated by DOE, Yankee shall use a projection of the period required for the completion of the transfer of spent nuclear fuel and greater than Class C waste, the decontamination and dismantlement of the ISFSI, and the wind up of its corporate affairs in lieu of the fifteen-year period specified in section 1(b)(iii), above. If the NRC issues a regulation, order or other directive requiring a demonstration of financial assurance for spent fuel storage operations greater than that provided by the use of the fifteen-year period specified in section 1(b)(iii), above, Yankee shall use a period sufficient to satisfy the NRC requirement in the calculation of the Financial Assurance Level. Yankee shall implement either such change through an application to FERC under section 205 of the Federal Power Act, as provided in section 5, below. 2. Within sixty days of its receipt of DOE Proceeds, Yankee shall provide its calculation of the Financial Assurance Level in accordance with section 1(b), calculated as of the end of the most recent calendar quarter for which data are available, and the application of the DOE Proceeds in accordance with section 1(a) to the entities that executed the Stipulation and Settlement Agreement submitted to FERC in the application that proposed to add this Appendix E to the Additional Power Contract (the "Signatories"). a. Yankee shall include work papers supporting its calculations. Yankee shall also include notice of a technical conference (which may be conducted in person, by telephone or by internet conference) at which Yankee shall describe its calculation and to respond to questions regarding its calculation from any Signatory. The Signatories shall have fifteen business days from receipt of Yankee's calculation to provide to Yankee (with copies to all Signatories) any written objections to Yankee's calculation and Yankee shall have ten business days from receipt to provide to all Signatories written responses to any objections raised. Any Signatory may request in writing that Yankee provide information relevant to its calculation and Yankee shall endeavor in good faith to respond to such requests within ten days of receipt, provided that Yankee shall not be required to provide information protected by any privilege and the Signatories shall hold in confidence any information that Yankee identifies as proprietary or commercially sensitive. Any information that Yankee provides in response to such requests may be used in challenges to Yankee's informational filing, provided that any information that Yankee labels as proprietary or commercially sensitive shall be subject to FERC's procedures for the protection of such information. Yankee and any objecting Signatory shall negotiate in good faith to seek to resolve any objection for a period of forty-five days after an objection is provided, which period may be extended by mutual agreement among Yankee and all Signatories that presented objections that have not been resolved. b. If Yankee's calculation, adjusted if applicable to reflect the resolution of any objections through negotiations, results in a credit to Purchasers or a reduction in decommissioning charges or if Yankee proposes no change in decommissioning charges: i. Yankee shall submit an informational filing to the FERC within thirty days of: (i) the last day for submission of objections if no Signatory objects to Yankee's calculation; (ii) the date the last objection to Yankee's calculation is resolved through negotiations; or (iii) the end of the period provided in 2(a) for negotiations to attempt to resolve objections to Yankee's calculation, whichever date occurs last. In the informational filing, Yankee shall describe the results of the calculation of the Financial Assurance Level, reflecting, if applicable, the resolution of any objections raised by a Signatory, and any resulting reduction in decommissioning charges and any resulting credit to the Purchasers. Yankee shall implement the reduced decommissioning charges and provide any credit to the Purchasers beginning with the charge due for the first month beginning at least thirty days after the submission of the informational filing. ii. If any Signatory objects to Yankee's calculation and the objection is not resolved in accordance with section 2(a), above, that Signatory may protest or file comments on Yankee's informational filing, setting forth its objection or objections to Yankee's calculation and any Signatory may take any position on any such objection. In any proceeding established by FERC to review Yankee's informational filing: (i) the proceeding shall be limited to the issue of the consistency of Yankee's calculation with sections 1(a) and 1(b), unless FERC consolidates the proceeding with a proceeding established under section 205 or section 206 of the Federal Power Act; (ii) Yankee shall bear the burden of proving that its calculation is consistent with sections 1(a) and 1(b); and (iii) any adjustment to Yankee's decommissioning charges and/or credits based on a determination that Yankee's calculation was inconsistent with sections 1(a) and 1(b) shall take effect beginning with the charge due for the first month beginning at least thirty days after the FERC's order is issued, subject to rehearing and potential judicial review. iii. If a calculation is based on a pending decommissioning estimate, as specified in section 1(c), and the resolution of proceedings on that estimate requires Yankee to revise a calculation provided under this section 2, Yankee shall provide the revised calculation to the Signatories and the procedures set forth in section 2(a) and, if the revised calculation results in a further credit or reduction in decommissioning charges, the procedures set forth in section 2(b), shall apply to the revised calculation. c. If Yankee's calculation identifies a deficiency in the Decommissioning Trust Fund and Yankee proposes to resume or increase decommissioning charges, Yankee may at any time submit an application to implement such new or revised charges under section 205 of the Federal Power Act, as provided in section 4, below. If the procedures set forth in section 2(a) are under way at the time Yankee submits such an application, Yankee shall nevertheless complete those procedures. 3. If Yankee does not receive DOE proceeds within five years of the effective dates of the this Appendix E or, thereafter, within five years of the most recent informational filing described in section 2(b) or rate filing described in section 2(c), Yankee nevertheless provide its calculation of the Financial Assurance Level in accordance with section 1(b), calculated as of the end of the most recent calendar quarter for which data are available, to the Signatories. The procedures set forth in section 2(a) shall apply to the calculation. Yankee shall submit an informational filing to the FERC within thirty days of: (i) the last day for submission of objections if no Signatory objects to Yankee's calculation; (ii) the date the last objection to Yankee's calculation is resolved through negotiations; or (iii) the end of the period provided in the preceding sentence for negotiations to attempt to resolve objections to Yankee's calculation, whichever date occurs last. Yankee's informational filing shall describe the results of the calculation of the Financial Assurance Level. If Yankee proposes to initiate or modify any charges to the Purchasers in light of its calculation of the Financial Assurance Level, it may combine such informational filing with an application under section 205 of the Federal Power Act. 4. Nothing in this Appendix E shall restrict (i) the right of Yankee at any time to submit an application to the FERC under section 205 of the Federal Power Act to modify any of its rates or charges, including, without limitation, decommissioning charges and charges to recover expenses for postretirement benefits other than pensions, or the right of any other Signatory to take any position regarding such application; or (ii) the right of any Signatory at any time to submit a petition or complaint to the FERC under section 206 of the Federal Power Act to modify any of Yankee's rates or charges or the right of any other Signatory to take any position regarding such petition or complaint. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, if Yankee desires to modify the cost estimate or any of the other assumptions used to calculate the Financial Assurance Level under section 1(b), above, Yankee shall submit an application to the FERC proposing the change or changes it believes appropriate and Yankee shall bear the burden of proving that the change it proposes yields rates that are just, reasonable, and not unduly discriminatory or preferential. 5. Together with its second calculation of the Financial Assurance Level that Yankee provides to the Signatories pursuant to section 2 subsequent to September 1, 2019 or, if Yankee has not provided two such calculations by September 1, 2033, by no later than October 1, 2033, Yankee shall submit to the Signatories a recommendation either: (a) to continue the procedures set forth in this Appendix E; (b) to modify the procedures set forth in this Appendix E; or (c) to delete the procedures set forth in this Appendix E in whole or in part. Yankee shall consult with the Signatories regarding its recommendation during the period for review and negotiation of Yankee's Financial Assurance Level calculation under section 2(a), or, if the recommendation is not presented in connection with such a calculation, for a period of sixty days, which may be shortened or extended by mutual agreement among Yankee and the Signatories. If Yankee and the Signatories agree to continue the procedures set forth in this Appendix E, Yankee shall include a statement to that effect in the next informational filing it submits pursuant to section 2(b). If Yankee and the Signatories agree to modify or delete the procedures set forth in this Appendix E, Yankee shall include the necessary revisions to the Power Contract in an application to FERC under section 205 of the Federal Power Act. If Yankee and the Signatories cannot agree, Yankee shall submit its proposal in an application to FERC under section 205 and Yankee shall bear the burden of proving that its proposal is just, reasonable, and not unduly discriminatory or preferential. All Signatories shall have the right to take any position regarding Yankee's application. Nothing in this section 5 shall restrict any right of Yankee or any Signatory under section 4, including the right to propose modifications to this Appendix E prior to the date of Yankee's application under this section.
record_data.filing_title: Connecticut Yankee Rate Schedule Revision Filing

record_data.record_title: Review of Funding Adequacy & Future DOE Recovery Application
record_data.record_plain_text: Appendix E Review of Adequacy of Funding and Application of Future DOE Recoveries 1. Connecticut Yankee ("Yankee") has brought a civil action against the U.S. Department of Energy ("DOE") to recover damages suffered by Yankee during the period 2002 through 2008 caused by the failure of DOE to perform its obligations under its Standard Contract with Yankee under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982, and Yankee plans to file additional civil actions against the DOE to recover additional damages with respect to subsequent periods until DOE fully performs its obligations. Yankee shall apply any damages recovered from DOE in any such civil action and any proceeds received from DOE in settlement of any such civil action ("DOE Proceeds") as follows: a. Any DOE Proceeds that Yankee receives shall be applied as follows: i. First, the DOE Proceeds shall be applied to pay federal and state taxes due on the DOE Proceeds received; ii. Second, the remaining DOE Proceeds, if any, shall be deposited in the Decommissioning Trust Funds to the extent necessary to maintain the Financial Assurance Level, as defined in section 1(b) of this Appendix E; iii. Third, the remaining DOE Proceeds, if any, shall be deposited in an external trust fund to the extent necessary to fund Yankee's expense for post-retirement benefits other than pensions, after taxes, at the level most recently approved by the Commission. iv. Fourth, the remaining DOE Proceeds, if any, shall be applied to reduce uniformly any scheduled charges for funding of the Decommissioning Trust Funds; and v. Fifth, the remaining DOE Proceeds, if any, shall be credited to Purchasers in the manner set forth in section 2 of this Appendix E, below. b. For purposes of this Appendix E, "Financial Assurance Level" shall mean the funding required to be held in the Decommissioning Trust Funds to meet projected decommissioning costs, including costs of operating and maintaining the ISFSI and the costs of dismantling and decontaminating the ISFSI and the payment to DOE of the Spent Fuel Obligation associated with pre-1983 spent nuclear fuel. In calculating the Financial Assurance Level, Yankee shall use: i. the cost estimate and all associated financial assumptions most recently accepted by the FERC prior to the calculation of the Financial Assurance Level, except as specified in section 1(c), below; ii. information from the end of the most recent calendar quarter for which data are available with respect to (i) actual trust fund balances, (ii) actual trust fund investment earnings; (iii) actual decommissioning costs; and (iv) actual escalation of the Spent Fuel Obligation associated with pre-1983 spent nuclear fuel; and iii. the assumption that Yankee shall remain in operation for purposes of operating the ISFSI, decontaminating and dismantling the ISFSI and winding up its corporate affairs for a period of fifteen years after the date with respect to which the Financial Assurance Level is calculated, notwithstanding the date projected for the end of Yankee's corporate life in the cost estimate, unless section 1(d), below, applies; c. If Yankee has submitted a revised decommissioning cost estimate to the FERC that is pending before the FERC at the time Yankee is calculating the Financial Assurance Level, Yankee shall initially use the pending cost estimate and associated financial assumptions to calculate the Financial Assurance Level, provided that the calculation shall be trued-up to reflect any revisions to the cost estimate and financial assumptions required by the resolution of proceedings on the pending estimate. d. Once DOE has begun to transfer spent nuclear fuel from Yankee's ISFSI to a repository operated by DOE, Yankee shall use a projection of the period required for the completion of the transfer of spent nuclear fuel and greater than Class C waste, the decontamination and dismantlement of the ISFSI, and the wind up of its corporate affairs in lieu of the fifteen-year period specified in section 1(b)(iii), above. If the NRC issues a regulation, order or other directive requiring a demonstration of financial assurance for spent fuel storage operations greater than that provided by the use of the fifteen-year period specified in section 1(b)(iii), above, Yankee shall use a period sufficient to satisfy the NRC requirement in the calculation of the Financial Assurance Level. Yankee shall implement either such change through an application to FERC under section 205 of the Federal Power Act, as provided in section 5, below. 2. Within sixty days of its receipt of DOE Proceeds, Yankee shall provide its calculation of the Financial Assurance Level in accordance with section 1(b), calculated as of the end of the most recent calendar quarter for which data are available, and the application of the DOE Proceeds in accordance with section 1(a) to the entities that executed the Stipulation and Settlement Agreement submitted to FERC in the application that proposed to add this Appendix E to the Additional Power Contract (the "Signatories"). a. Yankee shall include work papers supporting its calculations. Yankee shall also include notice of a technical conference (which may be conducted in person, by telephone or by internet conference) at which Yankee shall describe its calculation and to respond to questions regarding its calculation from any Signatory. The Signatories shall have fifteen business days from receipt of Yankee's calculation to provide to Yankee (with copies to all Signatories) any written objections to Yankee's calculation and Yankee shall have ten business days from receipt to provide to all Signatories written responses to any objections raised. Any Signatory may request in writing that Yankee provide information relevant to its calculation and Yankee shall endeavor in good faith to respond to such requests within ten days of receipt, provided that Yankee shall not be required to provide information protected by any privilege and the Signatories shall hold in confidence any information that Yankee identifies as proprietary or commercially sensitive. Any information that Yankee provides in response to such requests may be used in challenges to Yankee's informational filing, provided that any information that Yankee labels as proprietary or commercially sensitive shall be subject to FERC's procedures for the protection of such information. Yankee and any objecting Signatory shall negotiate in good faith to seek to resolve any objection for a period of forty-five days after an objection is provided, which period may be extended by mutual agreement among Yankee and all Signatories that presented objections that have not been resolved. b. If Yankee's calculation, adjusted if applicable to reflect the resolution of any objections through negotiations, results in a credit to Purchasers or a reduction in decommissioning charges or if Yankee proposes no change in decommissioning charges: i. Yankee shall submit an informational filing to the FERC within thirty days of: (i) the last day for submission of objections if no Signatory objects to Yankee's calculation; (ii) the date the last objection to Yankee's calculation is resolved through negotiations; or (iii) the end of the period provided in 2(a) for negotiations to attempt to resolve objections to Yankee's calculation, whichever date occurs last. In the informational filing, Yankee shall describe the results of the calculation of the Financial Assurance Level, reflecting, if applicable, the resolution of any objections raised by a Signatory, and any resulting reduction in decommissioning charges and any resulting credit to the Purchasers. Yankee shall implement the reduced decommissioning charges and provide any credit to the Purchasers beginning with the charge due for the first month beginning at least thirty days after the submission of the informational filing. ii. If any Signatory objects to Yankee's calculation and the objection is not resolved in accordance with section 2(a), above, that Signatory may protest or file comments on Yankee's informational filing, setting forth its objection or objections to Yankee's calculation and any Signatory may take any position on any such objection. In any proceeding established by FERC to review Yankee's informational filing: (i) the proceeding shall be limited to the issue of the consistency of Yankee's calculation with sections 1(a) and 1(b), unless FERC consolidates the proceeding with a proceeding established under section 205 or section 206 of the Federal Power Act; (ii) Yankee shall bear the burden of proving that its calculation is consistent with sections 1(a) and 1(b); and (iii) any adjustment to Yankee's decommissioning charges and/or credits based on a determination that Yankee's calculation was inconsistent with sections 1(a) and 1(b) shall take effect beginning with the charge due for the first month beginning at least thirty days after the FERC's order is issued, subject to rehearing and potential judicial review. iii. If a calculation is based on a pending decommissioning estimate, as specified in section 1(c), and the resolution of proceedings on that estimate requires Yankee to revise a calculation provided under this section 2, Yankee shall provide the revised calculation to the Signatories and the procedures set forth in section 2(a) and, if the revised calculation results in a further credit or reduction in decommissioning charges, the procedures set forth in section 2(b), shall apply to the revised calculation. c. If Yankee's calculation identifies a deficiency in the Decommissioning Trust Fund and Yankee proposes to resume or increase decommissioning charges, Yankee may at any time submit an application to implement such new or revised charges under section 205 of the Federal Power Act, as provided in section 4, below. If the procedures set forth in section 2(a) are under way at the time Yankee submits such an application, Yankee shall nevertheless complete those procedures. 3. If Yankee does not receive DOE proceeds within five years of the effective dates of the this Appendix E or, thereafter, within five years of the most recent informational filing described in section 2(b) or rate filing described in section 2(c), Yankee nevertheless provide its calculation of the Financial Assurance Level in accordance with section 1(b), calculated as of the end of the most recent calendar quarter for which data are available, to the Signatories. The procedures set forth in section 2(a) shall apply to the calculation. Yankee shall submit an informational filing to the FERC within thirty days of: (i) the last day for submission of objections if no Signatory objects to Yankee's calculation; (ii) the date the last objection to Yankee's calculation is resolved through negotiations; or (iii) the end of the period provided in the preceding sentence for negotiations to attempt to resolve objections to Yankee's calculation, whichever date occurs last. Yankee's informational filing shall describe the results of the calculation of the Financial Assurance Level. If Yankee proposes to initiate or modify any charges to the Purchasers in light of its calculation of the Financial Assurance Level, it may combine such informational filing with an application under section 205 of the Federal Power Act. 4. Nothing in this Appendix E shall restrict (i) the right of Yankee at any time to submit an application to the FERC under section 205 of the Federal Power Act to modify any of its rates or charges, including, without limitation, decommissioning charges and charges to recover expenses for postretirement benefits other than pensions, or the right of any other Signatory to take any position regarding such application; or (ii) the right of any Signatory at any time to submit a petition or complaint to the FERC under section 206 of the Federal Power Act to modify any of Yankee's rates or charges or the right of any other Signatory to take any position regarding such petition or complaint. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, if Yankee desires to modify the cost estimate or any of the other assumptions used to calculate the Financial Assurance Level under section 1(b), above, Yankee shall submit an application to the FERC proposing the change or changes it believes appropriate and Yankee shall bear the burden of proving that the change it proposes yields rates that are just, reasonable, and not unduly discriminatory or preferential. 5. Together with its second calculation of the Financial Assurance Level that Yankee provides to the Signatories pursuant to section 2 subsequent to September 1, 2019 or, if Yankee has not provided two such calculations by September 1, 2033, by no later than October 1, 2033, Yankee shall submit to the Signatories a recommendation either: (a) to continue the procedures set forth in this Appendix E; (b) to modify the procedures set forth in this Appendix E; or (c) to delete the procedures set forth in this Appendix E in whole or in part. Yankee shall consult with the Signatories regarding its recommendation during the period for review and negotiation of Yankee's Financial Assurance Level calculation under section 2(a), or, if the recommendation is not presented in connection with such a calculation, for a period of sixty days, which may be shortened or extended by mutual agreement among Yankee and the Signatories. If Yankee and the Signatories agree to continue the procedures set forth in this Appendix E, Yankee shall include a statement to that effect in the next informational filing it submits pursuant to section 2(b). If Yankee and the Signatories agree to modify or delete the procedures set forth in this Appendix E, Yankee shall include the necessary revisions to the Power Contract in an application to FERC under section 205 of the Federal Power Act. If Yankee and the Signatories cannot agree, Yankee shall submit its proposal in an application to FERC under section 205 and Yankee shall bear the burden of proving that its proposal is just, reasonable, and not unduly discriminatory or preferential. All Signatories shall have the right to take any position regarding Yankee's application. Nothing in this section 5 shall restrict any right of Yankee or any Signatory under section 4, including the right to propose modifications to this Appendix E prior to the date of Yankee's application under this section.
